prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Vela - HCO+ Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal covers all sources in the Vela Cloud in HCO+ 3--2. The other windows are aimed solely at continuum. This science goal will provide the bulk of the mass sensitivity.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Line goal HCO+ - density and excitation HCN - excitation
Other three windows are continuum. FDM mode is selected for these with a 1.2 km/s resolution to detect other lines. These are potential contaminants to the continuum and should be removed. TDM mode does not provide the necessary velocity resolution. Serendipitous lines are scientifically interesting as an astrochemical legacy on the most massive fragments
In this science goal, the achieved line sensitivy of 25 mJy in 0.1 km/s bins will produce SNRs of 8 per resolution element (>50 over the line), allowing us to very accurately determine central velocities. Lines are covered by 25 elements at even the thinnest lines (see Figure). Line widths of 4 km/s are not unlikely. Determining very accurate FWHM and total flux can be done by smoothing spectra to 0.5 km/s. In turn the sensitivity is much better than a SNR of 8
This science goal contains the best continuum sensitivity by using three aggregate windows to get a mass sensitivity below 0.01 solar mass. To improve mass sensitivity, continuum measurements of the science goal 2 can be combined.
Resolution The main text motivates the required resolution of 0.3 arcseconds.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Vela - C18O/13CO Band 6
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal covers all sources in the Vela Cloud in C18O, 13CO, H2CO triplet and DCN. It also contains two continuum windows.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Line goal C18O - column density 13CO - column density H2CO triplet - Temperature tracer. this is done using a multi-region mode as all three lines contribute to the temperature analysis. The best resolution is required, even though this is not the envisioned 0.1 km/s. DCN will be obtained for free. It allows for deuteration comparison with HCN. Last two windows are continuum. FDM mode is selected for these with a 2.5 km/s resolution to detect other lines. These are potential contaminants to the continuum and should be removed. TDM mode does not provide the necessary velocity resolution. Serendipitous lines are scientifically interesting as astrochemical legacy on the most massive fragments
In this science goal, the achieved line sensitivy of 17 mJy in 0.1 km/s bins will produce SNRs of 12 per resolution element (>50 over the line), allowing us to very accurately determine central velocities. Lines are covered by 25 elements at even the thinnest lines (see Figure). Line widths of 4 km/s are not unlikely. Determining very accurate FWHM and total flux can be done by smoothing spectra to 0.5 km/s. In turn the sensitivity is much better than a SNR of 12
Continuum sensitivity is no issue as envisioned mass sensitivity is easily reached by using 1.875 GHz window and the aggregate bandwidth.
Resolution The main text motivates the required resolution of 0.3 arcseconds.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Vela - HCO+ Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This science goal covers all sources in the Vela Cloud in HCO+ 4--3, H13CO+ 4--3 and HCN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Line goal HCO+ - density and excitation H13CO+ - optical depth.
Last two windows are continuum. FDM mode is selected for these with a 1.7 km/s resolution to detect other lines. These are potential contaminants to the continuum and should be removed. TDM mode does not provide the necessary velocity resolution. Serendipitous lines are scientifically interesting as an astrochemical legacy on the most massive fragments
In this science goal, the achieved line sensitivy of 30 mJy in 0.1 km/s bins will produce SNRs of 13 per resolution element (>50 over the line), allowing us to very accurately determine central velocities. Lines are covered by 50 elements. Determining very accurate FWHM and total flux can be done by smoothing spectra to 0.5 km/s. In turn the sensitivity is much better than a SNR of 13
Continuum sensitivity is no issue as envisioned mass sensitivity is easily reached by using 1.875 GHz windows and the aggregate bandwidth.
Resolution The main text motivates the required resolution of 0.3 arcseconds.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: What is the mass distribution within deeply embedded clusters where the bulk of stars in our Milky Way form? Competing theories on star formation make measurably different predictions on the fragmentation of collapsing molecular clouds. Intermediate mass star-forming clusters are ideal test-beds to study this. They provide environments unaltered by the energetic feedback that plagues massive star formation. In this ALMA proposal, we will measure the mass spectra of 11 embedded and fragmented star forming regions of intermediate mass in Vela D, with resolutions down at 250 AU and sensitivities down to 0.01 solar mass. We will observe the dust continuum and line emission of HCO+, C18O, H2CO and HCN to unambigiously derive the mass and physical conditions of the fragments. Only ALMA has the sensitivity and resolution to determine the complete mass spectrum of these regions, at scales that probe down to the individual protostar(s). Using the derived statistics, our observations will answer the question whether single protostar dominates the mass in the cluster or if they have broken up in fragments of equal mass.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Physics I, Cologne, University of
